Objects.name: e
Objects.Notes: If efficiency is greater than one, assume it is a percentage

Objects.name: H
Objects.Notes: The outlet enthalpy is determined by dividing the difference between the inlet and ideal outlet enthalpies by the efficiency and adding the result to the feed enthalpy.

Objects.name: Overview
Objects.Notes:
Polytropic Efficiency

This model calculates the polytropic efficiency for a compressor. The input expressions are: InletV - the molar volume of the inlet fluid inletP - the pressure of the inlet fluid inletH - the molar enthalpy of the inlet fluid Ideal - the flash results for the outlet fluid assuming isentropic compression. Outlet - the flash results for the actual outlet fluid The outlet expression is polyEff, the polytropic efficiency. The other expressions implement the calculation outlined below and where the expression calculates a variable mentioned here the the variable's symbol is listed in the expression notes.

Calculation overview

Polytropic efficiency can be defined as: Ep = Wp / Wa where: Ep = polytropic efficiency Wp = polytropic work Wa = actual work where the actual work Wa is: Wa = Ws / Ea where: Ea = adiabatic efficiency Ws = isentropic work and the adiabatic efficiency Eq can be calculated from: Ea = (hIout - hin) / (hAout - hin) where: hin is the enthalpy of the inlet fluid. hIOut is the enthalpy of the outlet for the ideal (isentropic) process. hAout is the enthalpy of the outlet for tne nonideal process. Back substituting Wa into the polytropic efficiency formula becomes: Ep = Ea * Wp / Ws The formulas for Wp and Ws are of the same form and after eliminating common terms from the numerator and denominator, we get Ep = Ea * ( n/(n-1) * ((p2/p1)^((n-1)/n) - 1) / ns/(ns-1) * ((p2/p1)^((ns-1)/ns) - 1) ) where: n = ln(p2/p1) / ln(v1/vs) ns = ln(p2/p1) / ln(v1/va) p1 = inlet pressure, p2 = outlet pressure v1 = inlet molar volume vs = isentropic outlet molar volume va = actual outlet molar volume If this is an expander then the actual efficiency is 1/Ep.

Formula.Formula:
adEff *
(
	n / (n - 1) *
	(
		(
			Outlet.p
			/
			inletP
		)^((n-1)/n)
		 - 1
	)
)
/
(
	ns/ (ns - 1) *
	(
		(
			Outlet.p
			/
			inletP
		)^((ns-1)/ns)
		- 1
	)
)

Objects.name: Overview
Objects.Notes:
Expander Overview

This model represents a thermodynamic model of an expander, which is a device that extracts work from the expansion of a fluid. It is essentially a compressor in reverse. The input expressions are: feed - a flash result or similar representing the inlet fluid outletP - the outlet pressure that the fluid will be reduced to. efficiency - the actual power produced divided by the ideal power produced. The outlet expressions are: out - the outlet fluid flash power - the power produced by the expansion polyEff - the calculated polytropic efficiency An ideal expander is first modeled by performing an isentropic flash using the outlet pressure and the feed entropy in tool IdealOut. The efficiency, e, of an non-ideal expander is taken to be: e = (hAout - hin) / (hIout - hin) where: hin is the enthalpy of the inlet fluid. hIOut is the enthalpy of the outlet for the ideal (isentropic) process. hAout is the enthalpy of the outlet for tne nonideal process. The desired efficiency is supplied in the input expression Efficiency so by rearranging, the expression H can calculate the nonideal outlet enthalpy, which is used with the outlet pressure to perform an isenthalpic flash in OutFluid. The power produced by the expander can then be calculated in expression Power by multiplying the flow by the difference between the inlet fluid enthalpy and the outlet fluid enthalpy.

Objects.name: e
Objects.Notes: If efficiency is greater than one, assume it is a percentage

Objects.name: H
Objects.Notes: The outlet enthalpy is determined by dividing the difference between the inlet and ideal outlet enthalpies by the efficiency and adding the result to the feed enthalpy.

Formula.Formula:
adEff *
(
	n / (n - 1) *
	(
		(
			Outlet.p
			/
			inletP
		)^((n-1)/n)
		 - 1
	)
)
/
(
	ns/ (ns - 1) *
	(
		(
			Outlet.p
			/
			inletP
		)^((ns-1)/ns)
		- 1
	)
)

Objects.name: Overview
Objects.Notes:
Polytropic Efficiency

This model calculates the polytropic efficiency for a compressor. The input expressions are: InletV - the molar volume of the inlet fluid inletP - the pressure of the inlet fluid inletH - the molar enthalpy of the inlet fluid Ideal - the flash results for the outlet fluid assuming isentropic compression. Outlet - the flash results for the actual outlet fluid The outlet expression is polyEff, the polytropic efficiency. The other expressions implement the calculation outlined below and where the expression calculates a variable mentioned here the the variable's symbol is listed in the expression notes.

Calculation overview

Polytropic efficiency can be defined as: Ep = Wp / Wa where: Ep = polytropic efficiency Wp = polytropic work Wa = actual work where the actual work Wa is: Wa = Ws / Ea where: Ea = adiabatic efficiency Ws = isentropic work and the adiabatic efficiency Eq can be calculated from: Ea = (hIout - hin) / (hAout - hin) where: hin is the enthalpy of the inlet fluid. hIOut is the enthalpy of the outlet for the ideal (isentropic) process. hAout is the enthalpy of the outlet for tne nonideal process. Back substituting Wa into the polytropic efficiency formula becomes: Ep = Ea * Wp / Ws The formulas for Wp and Ws are of the same form and after eliminating common terms from the numerator and denominator, we get Ep = Ea * ( n/(n-1) * ((p2/p1)^((n-1)/n) - 1) / ns/(ns-1) * ((p2/p1)^((ns-1)/ns) - 1) ) where: n = ln(p2/p1) / ln(v1/vs) ns = ln(p2/p1) / ln(v1/va) p1 = inlet pressure, p2 = outlet pressure v1 = inlet molar volume vs = isentropic outlet molar volume va = actual outlet molar volume

Objects.name: Overview
Objects.Notes:
Compressor

This model represents a thermodynamic model of a compressor, although it can also stand in for a pump. The input expressions are: feed - a flash result or similar representing the inlet fluid outletP - the outlet pressure to compress to. efficiency - the ideal power needed divided by the actual power needed The outlet expressions are: out - the outlet fluid flash power - the power required for the compression polyEff - the calculated polytropic efficiency An ideal compressor is first modeled by performing an isentropic flash using the outlet pressure and the feed entropy in tool IdealOut. The efficiency, e, of an non-ideal compressor is taken to be: e = (hIout - hin) / (hAout - hin) where: hin is the enthalpy of the inlet fluid hIOut is the enthalpy of the outlet for the ideal (isentropic) process hAout is the enthalpy of the outlet for tne nonideal process The desired efficiency is supplied in the input expression Efficiency so by rearranging, the expression H can calculate the nonideal outlet enthalpy, which is used with the outlet pressure to perform an isenthalpic flash in OutFluid. The power required for the compressor can then be calculated in expression Power by multiplying the flow by the difference between the outlet fluid enthalpy and the inlet fluid enthalpy.

Objects.name: HotDt
Objects.Notes: The temperature approach between the heat source fluid and the boiled outlet temperature

Objects.name: PowerOut
Objects.Notes: Doesn't account for air cooler fan power

Objects.name: Overview
Objects.Notes:
Organic Rankine Cycle

This model represents a simple system for recovering energy from fluid with a poor heat quality. That is they aren't very hot. A low boiling fluid is used to permit boiling and super heating at reasonable temperatures. The superheated gas is then reduced in pressure in a turbine, recovering energy. The low pressure gas is condensed, typically in an air cooler, and then pumped back up to pressure and introduced into the boiler. The envelope plot and the lines representing the changes in pressure and temperature at each stage is a valuable tool for trying to get the best result. The turbine line should always be in the vapour phase and the the pump line should always be in liquid region.

Objects.name: SuperheatP
Objects.Notes: How much the boiler pressure is below the saturation pressure for super heating
